document_description: This document is a investment strategy report from WS Global CIO Office, outlining their expectations for the financial markets in 2026. The main topics covered include the anticipated continuation of the AI boom, the preference for diversification across various asset classes, and the expected themes of equities, income, and diversifiers. The report also mentions risks such as AI disappointment, contagious credit events, and central bank policy changes. The document includes a macroeconomic overview, perspectives on key client questions, and performance review, among other sections.

nodes.title: Outlook 2026
nodes.summary: In the text, the author discusses the importance of mental health in the workplace and how employers can support their employees' wellbeing. They suggest implementing policies such as flexible work hours, mental health days, and open communication about mental health. The author also emphasizes the need for destigmatizing mental health issues and creating a culture that values employees' mental health as much as their physical health.

nodes.title: Discussion of an equity market bubble
nodes.summary: In the 2026 Outlook, 12m Foundation overweights suggest investing in global equities, gold, US and Asia ex-Japan equities, and emerging market bonds. Opportunistic ideas include gold miners, US tech, pharma, utilities, India large and mid-cap, China non-financial high-dividend entities, Hang Seng Technology index, Europe banks, US Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities, short-duration high-yield bonds, AAA-rated Collateralized Loan Obligations, and Asian investment-grade bonds. The outlook anticipates risky assets to outperform in 2026 due to an AI boom, easing fiscal and monetary policies, and abating trade tensions. Themes include equities, income, and diversifiers. Risks include disappointment with Artificial Intelligence, contagious credit event, a Fed policy reversal, or a hawkish BoJ.

nodes.title: Foundation asset allocation models
nodes.summary: The text outlines the investment outlook for various asset classes as of 2026, according to Standard Chartered's Global Investment Committee. USD cash is expected to have falling yields and underperform major asset classes. Bonds, particularly high-quality government and corporate bonds, offer yield benefits but come with risks such as inflation sensitivity and elevated valuations. Emerging market bonds and currencies, Asia USD, and gold are attractive due to lower US rates, central bank rate cuts, and falling real yields, but come with risks like US trade policy. Equities in North America, Europe ex-UK, and Asia ex-Japan are expected to see earnings growth and policy support, but face challenges from valuations, US policy uncertainty, and growth concerns. Private assets and hedge fund strategies are suggested as portfolio hedges with illiquidity premiums, but come with risks of unexpected growth or credit quality worsening and high manager dispersion. The figure shows the performance of Standard Chartered's Foundation Allocations for the 12-month, 3-month, and 1-month periods ending December 2025.

nodes.title: Foundation: Our tactical asset allocation
nodes.summary: The text discusses the expectation of a weak USD in 2026, with a potential dip below 7.00 in USD/CNH. The USD's recovery since September has weakened due to soft US labor market data and anticipated Fed rate cuts. While a modest rebound is expected in the short term, long-term USD depreciation is anticipated due to Fed rate cuts supporting a cooling job market and reducing the USD's yield advantage. Major currencies, such as the JPY and EUR, are expected to appreciate against the USD. Chinese policymakers may allow USD/CNH to dip below 7.00 but are likely to intervene to defend key levels, with the pair expected to move to 7.02 in three months and stabilize around 7.00 in 12 months. The Fed is predicted to cut rates more than its DM peers.

nodes.title: Perspectives on key client questions
nodes.summary: India's equity market underperformed in 2025 due to lackluster earnings, stretched valuations, and persistent foreign investor outflows. However, improved valuations, earnings recovery driven by policy measures, and under-investment by foreign investors indicate a potential turnaround in 2026, leading to an upgrade of Indian equities to an Overweight within Asia ex-Japan, with a short-term bullish opportunity.

nodes.title: Macro overview at a glance
nodes.summary: In Outlook 2026, it is predicted that the US economy will experience a soft landing, growing below its long-term trend of 1.8% but avoiding a recession in 2026. Drivers of this view include easing trade tensions, Fed rate cuts, tax incentives, and AI developments. Consumption is resilient due to high-income households and limited impact of tariffs on goods inflation. The Fed is expected to continue rate cuts, and a weaker USD will further ease financial conditions. Trade tensions are easing with trade deals and a Supreme Court decision on tariffs pending. Tax cuts and the latest budget have given significant benefits to businesses and individuals, with a positive impact on GDP, and the Fed is projected to cut rates by 75bps to 3.0% by the end of 2026.

nodes.title: Asset classes
nodes.summary: In the text, the author discusses the importance of mental health in the workplace and the negative impact of stress on employees' well-being and productivity. They suggest that employers can promote mental health by creating a supportive work environment, offering resources such as counseling services and flexible work arrangements, and encouraging open communication about mental health concerns. The author emphasizes that prioritizing mental health not only benefits employees but also leads to a more engaged and productive workforce.

nodes.title: Bonds
nodes.summary: Outlook 2026 suggests an Overweight position on EM USD and LCY government bonds due to their high nominal yields and improved external balance of EM economies. The Fed's expected monetary policy easing and weak USD should benefit EM debt servicing. DM IG government bonds are recommended as a core holding, with yields expected to fall as the Fed cuts rates, resulting in strong total returns. Rates volatility is anticipated, but brief, and US 10-year government bond yields above 4.25% are seen as attractive. Asia USD bonds also offer attractive yields due to Chinese policy stimulus.

nodes.title: Equity
nodes.summary: Outlook 2026: The investment strategy includes an Overweight position in US equities due to resilient economic data, expectations of further Fed rate cuts, and continued earnings strength. Asia ex-Japan equities are also Overweighted, with benefits from a weaker USD, de-escalating trade tensions, and compelling valuations, particularly in India, where signs of a turnaround are emerging due to ongoing fiscal measures and robust domestic growth. Key risks include sentiment towards AI-related stocks and tariff risks in Asia ex-Japan.

nodes.title: Equity opportunistic views
nodes.summary: Outlook 2026: Outlook for 2026 includes an Overweight recommendation for the healthcare sector in the US, Europe, and China, with a focus on the US pharmaceuticals industry due to attractive valuations and earnings growth. Regulatory uncertainty in the US healthcare sector receded in Q3 2025, leading to a rebound. European financials are Overweight due to attractive valuations and fiscal stimulus, while US financials are more expensive but benefit from deregulation and a soft-landing. China financials remain inexpensive due to exposure to risks.

nodes.title: The case for Alternatives
nodes.summary: The text discusses the impact of inflation on the correlation between equities and bonds, suggesting that at higher inflation levels, the correlation between the two increases. This means that a traditional 60:40 equity bond portfolio may be less effective at managing portfolio volatility, leading to an increased incentive for investors to allocate up to 30% of their portfolio to non-traditional asset classes like alternatives. The figure provided illustrates the suggested asset allocation pie charts across different risk profiles, with a decrease in equity and fixed income allocations and an increase in alternatives as inflation rises.

nodes.title: Gold and crude oil
nodes.summary: The USD index (DXY) is expected to peak around 100.5 in the next three months due to the Fed's cautious stance on policy easing and geopolitical uncertainty in Asia. However, over a 12-month horizon, the USD is expected to weaken towards 96, as the Fed eases policy while other major central banks approach the end of their rate-cut cycles. Key charts indicate USD consolidation in the short term and weakness in the long term against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc. Political and institutional uncertainties, such as US trade policy and Fed independence, also weigh on the USD.

nodes.title: FX
nodes.summary: The text provides currency forecasts and drivers for EUR/USD, GBP/USD, USD/JPY, AUD/USD, and NZD/USD for the year 2026. The Euro is expected to depreciate slightly against the US Dollar in the near term due to subdued Euro area growth, but the ECB's interest rate hold and Germany's investment plan should boost the Euro over the next 12 months. The British Pound is under pressure from soft UK growth and cautious BoE guidance, but investor confidence and stabilizing fiscal policy could lift the GBP over the next year. The USD/JPY pair is expected to consolidate around 155 near term but decline in 2026 due to divergent central bank policies between the Fed and the BoJ. The AUD/USD pair is expected to decline to 0.64 due to excessive RBA rate hike expectations and muted Chinese growth. The NZD/USD pair is predicted to be moderately bullish over 12 months due to booming dairy and meat exports, but the RBNZ's potential easing and more rate cuts are risks. USD/CAD is expected to remain rangebound.

nodes.title: Additional perspectives
nodes.summary: In the text, the author discusses the importance of mental health in the workplace and the negative impact of stress on employees' productivity and well-being. The author argues that employers should prioritize mental health initiatives, such as flexible work arrangements, employee assistance programs, and open communication, to create a supportive work environment and reduce stress levels. By investing in mental health, employers can improve employee morale, reduce turnover, and boost overall productivity.

nodes.title: Quant perspective: Bullish equities over both short and long term
nodes.summary: The Outlook 2026 report predicts a bullish market environment for risky assets, including equities and bonds, with both long-term (3-6 months) and short-term (1-3 months) models indicating favorable conditions. The bullish equities view is based on constructive earnings revision and macro risk sentiment, low equity and moderate government bond market risks, and stable global inflation and growth rates. Factors supporting this view include positive equity momentum, net positive movements in interest rate benchmarks, and a disinflationary trend. Low government bond risk is attributed to soft private housing starts and manufacturing PMI, while strong equity gains and higher commodity prices make safe havens less attractive. Key model factors include economic activity, macro risk and surprise indices, corporate earnings, forward price-to-earnings ratio, technical factors, interest rates, commodity prices, and equity market momentum, among others.

nodes.title: Performance review
nodes.summary: The text discusses the current state of government bonds and credit markets, highlighting improved starting yields for bonds and stable income with tighter spreads in credit markets. Despite elevated equity-bond correlations, bonds are regaining their diversification benefits. In credit markets, while spreads have tightened, all-in yields remain attractive due to rising base rates. Equities are expected to deliver moderate returns despite challenging valuations.

nodes.title: Foundation: Asset allocation summary
nodes.summary: The text provides an asset allocation summary from the Foundation+ Outlook 2026 report by Standard Chartered. The summary includes percentages for cash, fixed income, equity, alternatives, and various subcategories within each asset class. Cash has the least allocation at 2%, while equities have the highest at 56%. Fixed income includes DM IG Government Bonds*, DM IG Corporate Bonds*, DM HY Corporate Bonds, EM USD Government Bonds, EM Local Ccy Government Bonds, and Asia USD Bonds. Alternatives consist of Gold, Hedge Fund Strategies, Private Equity, Private Real Assets, Private Debt, and Digital Assets. The figures may not add up to 100 due to rounding. The legend indicates that '▲' represents most preferred, '▼' least preferred, and '◆' core holdings.

nodes.title: Foundation+: Asset allocation summary
nodes.summary: This table displays the weekly and year-to-date performance of various asset classes, including Macro CTAs, Equity Long/Short, Event Driven, Relative Value, Composite, Diversified Commodity, and specific sectors and regions, as of 11 December 2025. The returns are presented in USD terms, with YTD data from 31 December 2024 to 11 December 2025 and 1-week data from 4 December 2025 to 11 December 2025. The asset classes include equities, bonds, currencies, and commodities across various regions and sectors. The performance ranges from a loss of 40% for some alternatives to gains of up to 85.8% for certain emerging markets.

nodes.title: Market performance summary
nodes.summary: This document outlines exchange rates, interest rates, and economic indicators for various currencies and countries, including the US, EU, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, China, Switzerland, and oil and gold prices. Key events such as PMI releases, nonfarm payrolls, and central bank policy meetings are listed for the US, EU, Japan, and the UK from January to June 2023 and 2026.

nodes.title: Our key forecasts and calendar events
nodes.summary: This text emphasizes the importance of wisely managing one's time and wealth, particularly in regards to investment planning. The text encourages individuals to review their current wealth strategy and consider whether their portfolio is optimally positioned for the future. The 'Today, Tomorrow, Forever' approach is introduced, which focuses on meeting current, short-term, and long-term wealth needs through well-diversified, long-term foundation portfolios and opportunistic investments.

nodes.title: SC Wealth Select
nodes.summary: Outlook 2026 emphasizes the importance of adhering to five time-tested Wealth Principles for successful investment decisions. These principles include Discipline to avoid emotional reactions, Diversification to reduce risk, Time in the Market for consistent returns, Risk and Return with appropriate balances, and Protection against financial uncertainty.
